content:
I made some versions for the list of emails that is displayed when someone wants to login with GitHub and has more verified email addresses associated with the GitHub account. You can view them here.

Looking forward for feedback!
All of these look great! cc @Tim Abbott + @Rishi Gupta
Great, thanks! Let's do "select account" instead of "select email"
Also, is it easy to pull in and display their GitHub avatar?

just had a chance to look on my computer. The first one looks great! And nice idea of using just the Z logo to represent "is a Zulip account".

For the text at the bottom ("Only verified ..") we can use the same styling we use for this "under the white box" text on other portico pages like this. E.g. https://zulipchat.com/accounts/go/ has some text like this.
All the email addresses will have the same GitHub avatar; we probably do have access to that data.
So we could display their name/GitHub handle, but it'd need to be in a section at the top.

I like the overall styling of option 1; I sorta feel like the individual options would benefit from having a border around them to make them look more card/button-like. For the ones that have an actual account, we could have cards that look like:

<avatar line 1> Tim Abbott
<avatar line 2> tabbott@example.com

(showing their Zulip avatar for that account in 2-line height, which along with name probably is a useful way to distinguish which of their 2 Zulip accounts in this organization is which)

and text more like this for the ones where there isn't an account

tabbott2@example.com
"Create new account" appears in the space you use for "primary" on hover
For the border: I'm imagining that'd be there on hover? I guess we can see how Google does it for their account selection modal
If all the github avatars would be the same we can skip it I think.
I like the Zulip avatar idea, along with putting "create new account"
Yeah, border on hover is reasonable.

Hi, I made a PR for this issue: #12930. I didn't do exactly as we discussed because it didn't look good in my opinion. So in the end I've put the avatars instead of the Zulip logo and I think it looks much cleaner this way. screenshot

This is how it looked with the Zulip logos and the avatars (I know it was not aligned but I didn't try aligning when I saw that it does not look good):
screenshot
looks great! As a small note we should proably not include the default github noreply address, since I think that won't work for actually creating teh account?
also, what does it look like when you have both "Github primary" and "Create new account" ?
Finally I tihnk it might make sense to put "Existing account" on the ones where there is an account, just like we put "Create new account" on the ones where there isn't an account

also, what does it look like when you have both "Github primary" and "Create new account" ?

Screen-Shot-2019-08-03-at-15.55.29.png
I added more pictures and gifs in the PR

looks great! As a small note we should proably not include the default github noreply address, since I think that won't work for actually creating teh account?

Thanks! I think you're right, I don't think anyone can use that email address for anything.

Finally I tihnk it might make sense to put "Existing account" on the ones where there is an account, just like we put "Create new account" on the ones where there isn't an account

And for the primary one? Should I add the "Existing account" as I added the "Create new account"?
yup! So each email will have either "Exsiting account" or "Create new account" depending on whether or not it has an associated Zulip account in the organization.

I found this:

You can set a primary email address on GitHub that's associated with web-based Git operations you perform such as edits and merges. Alternatively, you can choose to keep your personal email address private and use a GitHub-provided noreply email address for your web-based Git operations. (source)

So I think it might work creating the account with that email address.

I found this:

You can set a primary email address on GitHub that's associated with web-based Git operations you perform such as edits and merges. Alternatively, you can choose to keep your personal email address private and use a GitHub-provided noreply email address for your web-based Git operations. (source)

So I think it might work creating the account with that email address.

I just sent an email to my GitHub private address and I didn't receive a forwarded email or anything, so I don't think your extrapolation is correct.

So there was already a filter for the email addresses with @noreply.github.com which was not working anymore because probably GitHub changed it after this was implemented in Zulip. I added a commit to the PR in which I changed from @noreply.github.com to @users.noreply.github.com.
Yeh, those noreply email addresses do not work.
